From Wikipedia:Virtual private server:

This article discusses the use of Arch Linux on Virtual Private Servers, and includes some fixes and installation instructions specific to VPSes.

sections.title: Official Arch Linux cloud image
sections.content:
Arch Linux provides an official cloud image as part of the arch-boxes project. The image comes with Cloud-init preinstalled and should work with most cloud providers.

The image can be downloaded from the mirrors under the images directory. Instructions for tested providers is listed below.

sections.title: DigitalOcean
sections.content:
Website: Digital Ocean

Locations: Global

Steps to create Arch Linux VM:

1. Find the cloud image on a mirror, ex: https://geo.mirror.pkgbuild.com/images/latest/Arch-Linux-x86_64-cloudimg.qcow2
1. Add the image as a custom image by importing it
1. Create a new VM from the custom image
1. SSH to the VM: ssh root@ip

sections.title: Hetzner Cloud
sections.content:
Website: Hetzner Cloud

Locations: Nuremberg (Germany), Falkenstein (Germany), Helsinki (Finland), Singapur, Hillsboro (US West), Ashburn (US East)

Steps to create Arch Linux VM:

1. Create a new VM with this user data:#cloud-configvendor_data: {'enabled': false} The vendor_data from Hetzner overrides the distro and sets the default user to root without setting disable_root: false, meaning you can not login.
1. Boot the VM in rescue mode
1. SSH to the VM and download the cloud image from a mirror, ex: curl -O https://geo.mirror.pkgbuild.com/images/latest/Arch-Linux-x86_64-cloudimg.qcow2
1. Write the image to the disk: qemu-img convert -f qcow2 -O raw Arch-Linux-x86_64-cloudimg.qcow2 /dev/sda
1. Reboot the VM
1. SSH to the VM: ssh arch@ip

```
#cloud-configvendor_data: {'enabled': false}
```

The vendor_data from Hetzner overrides the distro and sets the default user to root without setting disable_root: false, meaning you can not login.

sections.title: Linode
sections.content:
Website: Linode

Locations: Multiple international locations

Steps to create Arch Linux VM:

1. Create a new VM and select Arch as the distribution (to use the Linode-provided image, stop here; otherwise proceed with the rest of the steps)
1. Boot the VM in rescue mode
1. Connect to the VM via the Lish console and download the basic image from a mirror, ex: curl -O https://geo.mirror.pkgbuild.com/images/latest/Arch-Linux-x86_64-basic.qcow2
1. Install the qemu-utils package: apt update && apt install qemu-utils
1. Write the image to the disk: qemu-img convert -f qcow2 -O raw Arch-Linux-x86_64-basic.qcow2 /dev/sda
1. In the Linode manager, go to the VM's configurations menu and edit the configuration to change the kernel option to "Direct Disk"
1. Reboot the VM
1. SSH to the VM: ssh arch@ip

sections.title: OVH Eco
sections.content:
Website: Kimsufi OVH Eco

Locations: Canada, France

Steps to create Arch Linux VM, paraphrasing the official documentation:

1. Navigate to the Dedicated Servers section in your OVH management panel, then select the server you want to deploy Arch Linux to.
1. Click the ... button next to "Last operating system (OS) installed by OVHcloud" and choose "Install"
1. Select "Install from custom image"
1. For "Image URL" put https://geo.mirror.pkgbuild.com/images/latest/Arch-Linux-x86_64-cloudimg.qcow2
1. For "Image type" select qcow2
1. For "Checksum type" select sha256
1. For "Image checksum" put the fingerprint value from https://geo.mirror.pkgbuild.com/images/latest/Arch-Linux-x86_64-cloudimg.qcow2.SHA256
1. Enable "ConfigDrive" to enter "Server host name" and your public "SSH key" (both are mandatory for Arch Cloud Init install)
1. Click "Install the system"
1. Wait (it takes a while) for an email from OVH titled "Installation of your image", it will say "Congratulations! Your dedicated server has just been installed! Connect to your server with ssh key provided during your installation."
1. Use ssh arch@ip to log in.

sections.title: Proxmox
sections.content:
Website: Proxmox

Locations: N/A

Steps to create Arch Linux VM:

1. Create a new VM.
1. Select "Do not use any media" in OS section.
1. Remove created hard disk from your VM after VM creation completes.
1. Add the downloaded image to your VM using qm disk import, ex: qm disk import 100 Arch-Linux-x86_64-cloudimg.qcow2 local.
1. Under Options, edit the boot order and add the newly-created disk.
1. Add a cloudinit drive and make your configurations in Cloud-Init section.
1. Start the VM!
